q: What is the purpose of ISA?
o: Provide international standards for conducting audits of financial statements

q: ISA stands for International Standards on Auditing.
The ______ is the international body that issues auditing standards.

o: High but not absolute level of assurance that financial statements are free from material misstatement
Magnitude of misstatement that could influence economic decisions of users

q: The ______ is the amount above which misstatements become significant.
Performance materiality is lower than overall materiality.

o: Risk that auditor expresses inappropriate opinion on materially misstated statements

q: The ______ risk is the risk that auditor procedures fail to detect misstatement.
Detection risk is controlled by the auditor.

o: Questioning mind and critical assessment of audit evidence
Overall objectives of independent auditor and conduct of audit

q: The ______ establishes overall objectives of the independent auditor.

o: Written agreement between auditor and client defining terms of engagement

q: Engagement letters are optional for recurring audits.

o: Agreeing the terms of audit engagements
Quality management for an audit of financial statements

q: The ______ standard covers audit documentation requirements.

o: Written record of procedures performed and conclusions reached

q: Working papers belong to the auditor.

o: Auditor's responsibilities relating to fraud in audit of financial statements

q: The ______ standard addresses the auditor's responsibility for fraud.
Auditors are responsible for detecting all fraud.

o: Three conditions for fraud: pressure, opportunity, and rationalization
Consideration of laws and regulations in audit of financial statements

q: The ______ requires auditors to consider laws and regulations.
Auditors are responsible for detecting all non-compliance.

o: Communication with those charged with governance

q: All audit findings must be communicated to those charged with governance.

o: Communicating deficiencies in internal control to those charged with governance

q: The ______ must be communicated in writing to those charged with governance.

o: Planning an audit of financial statements

q: The audit plan is more detailed than the audit strategy.

o: Identifying and assessing risks of material misstatement

q: The ______ standard requires understanding the entity and its environment.

o: Foundation of internal control providing discipline and structure

q: The control environment is the foundation of internal control.

o: Materiality in planning and performing an audit

q: The ______ sets guidance on determining and applying materiality.

o: Audit procedures to detect material misstatements at assertion level
Procedures to evaluate operating effectiveness of controls

q: The ______ are designed to test if controls operated effectively.
Tests of controls are required when relying on controls.

o: Audit considerations relating to entity using service organization
Evaluation of misstatements identified during audit

q: All identified misstatements must be corrected.
The ______ standard provides guidance on audit evidence.

o: Claims by management embodied in financial statements

q: The ______ assertion relates to whether transactions actually occurred.
Existence is tested by tracing from records to physical assets.

o: Audit evidence for specific items including inventory and litigation

q: The ______ confirmation requires response regardless of agreement.
Negative confirmations provide less reliable evidence.

o: Initial audit engagements including opening balances

q: The ______ procedures involve comparison of relationships between data.
Analytical procedures are required during planning phase.
The ______ is the risk of drawing incorrect conclusion from sample.

o: Auditing accounting estimates and related disclosures

q: Estimates require more skepticism due to uncertainty.
Related party transactions are always fraudulent.
The ______ events occur between financial statement date and audit report date.
Adjusting events require changes to financial statements.
The ______ requires management to assess going concern.
Going concern assessment covers at least 12 months from reporting date.
The ______ letter is required at end of every audit.
Representation letter substitutes for other audit evidence.
The ______ is responsible for the group audit opinion.
Group auditor can rely entirely on component auditor work.

o: Using the work of internal auditors

q: Internal audit work can reduce external audit procedures.

o: Using the work of an auditor's expert

q: The ______ expert provides expertise in non-accounting field.
The auditor is responsible for conclusions based on expert work.

o: Forming an opinion and reporting on financial statements

q: The ______ paragraph states whether financial statements are fairly presented.
Unmodified opinion is also called clean opinion.

o: Communicating key audit matters in the independent auditor's report

q: The ______ are matters of most significance in current audit.
KAMs are required for listed entity audits.

o: Modifications to opinion in independent auditor's report

q: The ______ opinion is issued when misstatement is material but not pervasive.
Adverse opinion means statements are materially misstated and pervasive.

o: Emphasis of matter paragraphs and other matter paragraphs

q: Emphasis of matter does not modify the opinion.
The ______ approach reports on current year as part of prior period.

o: Auditor's responsibilities relating to other information

q: The ______ includes reading other information for material inconsistency.
Auditor opines on other information in annual report.

o: Quality management for firms that perform audits

q: The ______ is responsible for firm's quality management system.
EQR must be completed before signing audit report.

o: Required discussions with those charged with governance

q: The ______ must include significant audit findings.
All communications must be in writing.

o: Application of relevant training and experience in making informed decisions

q: Professional judgment is required throughout the audit.

o: Finalizing audit file within specified time period

q: The ______ is typically 60 days after audit report date.
Audit files must be retained for minimum period.

o: Overall quality and signing of audit report

q: The engagement partner can delegate signing authority.
The ______ evidence is more reliable than internally generated.
Original documents are more reliable than copies.

o: Intentional or unintentional influence on financial information
Varying procedures to reduce predictability by those committing fraud
Testing entries for fraud risk especially manual and unusual entries

q: The ______ entries are higher risk for fraud.
All journal entries have equal fraud risk.

o: Controls over IT environment affecting all applications

q: The ______ controls ensure only authorized users access systems.
ITGC testing is required when relying on automated controls.

o: Controls specific to individual applications over input processing output

q: Input controls validate data entry accuracy.
What is data analytics in audit?
o: Using technology to analyze complete populations of transactions

q: The ______ analytics test entire populations rather than samples.
Data analytics can identify anomalies in entire populations.

o: Verifying transactions recorded in correct period

q: Cutoff errors always result in material misstatement.
The ______ is required when inventory is material.
Inventory observation can be waived if inventory is immaterial.

o: Verifying accuracy of client's bank reconciliation

q: Outstanding checks should clear within reasonable time.
The ______ confirmation requests customer to respond with balance.
Alternative procedures needed when confirmations not received.

o: Testing existence, ownership, and valuation of property plant equipment

q: Physical inspection verifies fixed asset existence.
The ______ for unrecorded liabilities examines payments after period end.
Vendor confirmations are commonly used for payables.

o: Verifying accuracy and authorization of employee compensation

q: Ghost employee fraud involves fictitious employees on payroll.
What is provisions and contingencies testing?
o: Evaluating completeness and measurement of provisions

q: The ______ letter requests information about litigation.

o: Verifying revenue recorded according to appropriate standards

q: Revenue recognition is presumed fraud risk area.

o: Verifying expenses recorded in appropriate accounts

q: Improper capitalization of expenses overstates assets.

o: Verifying accuracy of issued shares and share transactions

q: The ______ provides independent verification of shareholders.
What is related party disclosure audit?
o: Verifying completeness and accuracy of related party disclosures

q: All related party transactions are at arm's length.

o: Verifying segment identification and disclosure requirements

q: The ______ determines operating segments based on internal reporting.
Segment information must reconcile to financial statements.

o: Verifying temporary differences and deferred tax calculations

q: Deferred tax assets require realizability assessment.

o: Evaluating fair value measurements and disclosures

q: The ______ hierarchy classifies fair value inputs.
Level 3 fair values require significant auditor judgment.

o: Auditing elimination entries and consolidation process

q: All intercompany transactions must be eliminated.

o: External review of audit quality by oversight body

q: The ______ may result in sanctions for audit deficiencies.
Audit firms can refuse regulatory inspection.

o: Identifying underlying reasons for audit deficiencies

q: Root cause analysis prevents recurrence of deficiencies.

o: Mandatory change of partner after specified period

q: The ______ period is typically 5-7 years for listed entities.
The ______ threat arises from close relationships with client.
All threats can be mitigated with safeguards.

o: Non-audit service that cannot be provided to audit client

q: Internal audit outsourcing to external auditor is prohibited for listed clients.

o: When significant portion of firm revenue comes from one client

q: The ______ threshold is typically 15% of total firm revenue.
Contingent fees for audit services are prohibited.

o: Additional report content beyond traditional opinion
Combined audit of financial statements and internal controls

q: The ______ audit combines financial and control attestation.
Integrated audits are required for US listed companies.

o: Assurance on subject matter other than financial statements

q: Attestation engagements follow similar principles to audits.

o: Limited assurance engagement with negative assurance conclusion

q: The ______ negative assurance states nothing came to attention.
Review engagements provide less assurance than audits.

o: Auditor independently executing procedures or controls originally performed by entity

q: The ______ procedure involves independently executing entity controls.
Reperformance provides strong evidence of control effectiveness.

o: Checking mathematical accuracy of documents or records

q: Recalculation can be performed manually or using technology.

o: Tracing transaction from initiation through recording to understand process

q: The ______ helps auditor understand the complete transaction flow.
Walkthroughs are typically performed during planning.

o: Test that simultaneously evaluates control effectiveness and tests for misstatements

q: Dual purpose tests are more efficient than separate tests.
The ______ defines the individual items that make up the population.
Sampling unit must be appropriate for the audit objective.

o: Dividing population into subgroups with similar characteristics
Sampling method where each monetary unit has equal chance of selection

q: The ______ sampling gives higher selection probability to larger balances.
MUS is appropriate for testing for overstatement.

o: Maximum rate of deviation from prescribed control the auditor will accept

q: Lower tolerable deviation rate requires larger sample.
What is confidence level in sampling?
o: Complement of sampling risk expressed as percentage

q: The ______ confidence level means 5% sampling risk.
Higher confidence requires larger sample size.

o: Estimating total population misstatement from sample results

q: Projected misstatement can exceed tolerable misstatement.

o: Technique used to choose items from population

q: The ______ selection uses a random start and fixed interval.
Random selection provides best basis for statistical inference.

o: Error arising from isolated event not expected to recur

q: Anomalous errors are not projected to the population.
What is test of operating effectiveness?
o: Testing whether control operated effectively throughout the period

q: The ______ testing updates interim control testing to year end.
Control testing can be rotated over multiple years.
What is nature of audit procedures?
o: Type and purpose of audit procedures performed

q: Higher risk requires more effective procedures.

o: Account balance containing risk of material misstatement

q: The ______ accounts require focused audit attention.

o: Assertion that has reasonable possibility of containing material misstatement

q: Not all assertions are relevant for every account.

o: Computer Assisted Audit Techniques using technology for testing

q: The ______ allow testing of complete populations.

o: Processing auditor-created data through client's system

q: Test data may contaminate client's production data.

o: Creating fictitious entity within client's system for testing

q: The ______ creates a fictitious department for testing.
ITF allows testing in production environment.

o: Reprocessing client data using auditor's program
Analyzing reports of transactions outside normal parameters

q: The ______ reports highlight unusual or suspicious transactions.

o: Statement that nothing came to auditor's attention indicating misstatement

q: Negative assurance is appropriate for review engagements.

o: Assembling financial information without providing assurance

q: Compilation requires less work than review.

o: Performing specific procedures agreed with client and reporting findings

q: AUP reports provide no opinion or conclusion.

o: Financial information based on assumptions about future events

q: The ______ is based on assumptions management expects to occur.
Examination of forecasts provides limited assurance.

o: Financial reporting framework designed for specific users' needs

q: Special purpose reports may have restricted distribution.

o: Condensed financial information derived from complete statements

q: The ______ opinion relates to consistency with audited statements.
Summary statements require separate audit opinion.
What is single financial statement audit?
o: Audit of one financial statement or specific element

q: Single statement audit follows same standards as full audit.

o: Audit to assess conformity with specific requirements

q: The ______ audit assesses adherence to specific requirements.
Compliance audits may result in adverse findings.

o: Assessment of economy efficiency and effectiveness of operations

q: Performance audits focus on value for money.

o: Investigation of fraud or other irregularities

q: The ______ audit involves detailed investigation of suspected fraud.
Forensic auditors may provide expert testimony.
What is internal control material weakness?
o: Deficiency where reasonable possibility of material misstatement not prevented or detected

q: Material weakness requires disclosure in audit report.

o: Written confirmation about reasonableness of significant estimates

q: The ______ should address key estimates and assumptions.
Representations about estimates are required in the rep letter.

o: Required communication between incoming and outgoing auditors

q: Predecessor auditor communication requires client consent.

o: Evaluating impact of climate and ESG matters on financial statements

q: The ______ may affect asset valuations and provisions.
Sustainability matters may be material to financial statements.
What is auditor's use of artificial intelligence?
o: Using AI tools to enhance audit procedures and analysis
Real-time or near real-time automated audit procedures

q: The ______ provides ongoing assurance rather than point-in-time.
Continuous auditing identifies issues faster than traditional audit.

o: Auditing transactions recorded on distributed ledger technology

q: Blockchain may provide stronger evidence of transactions.

o: Assessing controls over information security and data protection

q: The ______ audit evaluates protection against cyber threats.
Cybersecurity risks can impact financial statement audit.

o: Assessing controls over data and applications hosted in cloud

q: Cloud service provider controls affect audit approach.

o: Assessing compliance with data protection regulations

q: The ______ regulations include GDPR and similar laws.
Data privacy compliance may affect audit procedures.
What is service organization control report?
o: Report on controls at service provider relevant to user entities

q: The ______ report covers controls over financial reporting.
Type 2 SOC reports test operating effectiveness.
What is carve-out vs inclusive method?
o: How subservice organizations are addressed in SOC reports

q: Carve-out method excludes subservice organization controls.
What is complementary user entity control?
o: Control at user entity needed for service organization control to be effective

q: The ______ controls are user's responsibility to implement.
User entities must implement complementary controls.

o: Letter from predecessor auditor updating information since SOC report date

q: Bridge letters address the gap period after SOC report date.
What is shared service center audit?
o: Auditing centralized function serving multiple entities

q: Shared service center issues affect multiple entities.

o: Communication to management about control weaknesses and recommendations
Benefits of audit to stakeholders beyond opinion on financial statements

q: The audit provides value beyond the opinion.

o: Difference between what public expects and what audit provides

q: The ______ gap exists between user expectations and audit reality.
Extended reporting helps reduce expectation gap.

o: How well audit committee fulfills its oversight role

q: Effective audit committee enhances financial reporting quality.

o: Legal responsibility of auditor for negligent conduct

q: The ______ exposure arises from negligent audit performance.
Auditors can be liable for negligent performance.
What is engagement letter scope limitation?
o: Restriction on scope of work due to client limitations

q: Scope limitation may result in modified opinion.

o: Date when auditor has obtained sufficient appropriate evidence

q: The report date is when ______ has been obtained.
Report dating affects subsequent events responsibility.

o: Using two dates on audit report for different subsequent events

q: Dual dating limits auditor responsibility to specific subsequent event.
What is reference to other auditor?
o: Referencing component auditor work in group audit report

q: The ______ is responsible for group opinion despite reference.
Reference to other auditor divides responsibility.

o: Not performing required audit procedure discovered after report

q: Discovered omissions may require report revision.
What is error discovered after report?
o: Material misstatement found after audit opinion issued

q: The ______ is an extreme measure for serious issues.

o: Activities performed before accepting or continuing audit engagement

q: The ______ are performed before engagement acceptance.
Preliminary activities are required for every engagement.

q: The principal auditor takes overall responsibility for the group opinion.

o: Advantages from continued engagement including accumulated knowledge

q: Recurring engagements benefit from accumulated knowledge.

o: Focusing audit effort on areas of highest risk

q: The ______ approach directs resources to highest risk areas.
Risk-based audit is more efficient than comprehensive testing.
What is inherent limitation of audit?
o: Factors that prevent audit from providing absolute assurance

q: Inherent limitations exist regardless of auditor competence.
What is surprise element in auditing?
The ______ element helps detect concealed fraud.
Surprise elements increase fraud detection likelihood.
What is revenue fraud risk presumption?
o: Presumption that revenue recognition involves fraud risk requiring rebuttal

q: Revenue recognition is presumed area of fraud risk.
What is management override of controls?
o: Ability of management to circumvent controls

q: The ______ is an inherent risk that cannot be eliminated.
All entities face management override risk.
What is auditor expert use decision?
o: Determining whether to use expert based on nature and complexity

q: The auditor remains responsible when using expert.

q: Modified reports may affect entity's reputation.

q: The ______ are selected from matters communicated to those charged with governance.

q: Material uncertainty about going concern requires disclosure.

o: Achieving audit objectives with minimum necessary work

Efficiency should not compromise audit quality.

q: The ______ bodies set ethical and technical standards.

o: Entity with significant public interest requiring enhanced audit requirements

q: The ______ entities face enhanced independence requirements.
PIE audits require key audit matters disclosure.
What is group audit significance threshold?

q: Significant components require full audit procedures.

q: The group auditor evaluates ______ before relying on component work.

o: Audit of parent and subsidiaries combined financial statements
Committee approval required before providing non-audit services

q: Transparency reports are required for PIE auditors.

q: Mandatory rotation aims to enhance independence.

o: Engagement with two or more audit firms sharing responsibility

q: Joint audits are required in some jurisdictions for large entities.

q: The ______ includes use of AI, data analytics, and automation.
Innovation enhances audit quality and efficiency.
